de.upb.t2t.control.gui.phonetic_keyboard

Class PhoneticKeyboardHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.upb.t2t.control.gui.phonetic_keyboard.PhoneticKeyboardHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.EventListener, javafx.event.EventHandler<javafx.scene.input.KeyEvent>

    public class PhoneticKeyboardHandler
extends java.lang.Object
implements javafx.event.EventHandler<javafx.scene.input.KeyEvent>

    This event handler offers functionality to transform any control that accepts KeyEvents into a phonetic keyboard. This means that nothing will change for input such as "b", "d", "f", etc. However, as soon as the user type in for example the character "t", a PhoneticSoundsChoice will pop up and present them with a choice as to which phonetic symbol they may want to type. In this case, the PhoneticSoundsChoice would offer the following symbols: /t/, /tʃ/, /dʒ/, /θ/ and /ð/.

    Please note that for the sake of easier coding, the term 'character' is not always used consistently for the Java primitive char throughout this class. This is because the JavaFx KeyEvent class by nature of its design oftentimes works with String objects of length 1 instead of chars, as for example in KeyEvent.getCharacter().

    Author:
    Michel May (michel-may@gmx.de)

    • Field Detail

      • inputControl

        private final javafx.scene.control.TextInputControl inputControl
        The input control that the listener listens to.

      • keyToken

        private final java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicBoolean keyToken
        While the PhoneticSoundsChoice is showing, all KeyEvents sent to the inputControl will be consumed. Should the user have decided on a phonetic symbol, however, this token is used to allow the corresponding event to pass through to the inputControl.

      • popup

        private final javafx.stage.Popup popup
        The popup to be displayed by the listener.

    • Method Detail

      • handle

        public void handle(javafx.scene.input.KeyEvent event)
        This function has two purposes: displaying the correct PhoneticSoundsChoice if required, and blocking any input headed towards the inputControl while said popup is showing.
        Specified by:
        handle in interface javafx.event.EventHandler<javafx.scene.input.KeyEvent>
        Parameters:
        event - the key event.

      • sendChoice

        protected void sendChoice(java.lang.String phoneticChas)
        Should be called when the user has made their decision in the PhoneticSoundsChoice and now that character needs to be sent to the inputControl.
        Parameters:
        phoneticChas - the character(s) to send to the input control.
        See Also:
        PhoneticSoundsChoice.onAction(ActionEvent)

      • hidePopup

        protected void hidePopup()
        Hides the popup.
        See Also:
        PhoneticSoundsChoice.onKeyPressed(KeyEvent)

      • computePopupCoords

        private javafx.util.Pair<java.lang.Double,java.lang.Double> computePopupCoords()
        A convenience function that computes where the popup should be displayed.
        Returns:
        the pair of coordinates at which the popup should be displayed.

      • popuplate

        private void popuplate(java.lang.String typedCha)
        Popuplates the popup with the appropriate PhoneticSoundsChoice pane based on what character is given as a parameter. Passing this function an "a" for example would lead to the aSounds being added to the popup.
        Parameters:
        typedCha - the character typed by the user.

      • isSpecialPermissonCharacter

        private boolean isSpecialPermissonCharacter(java.lang.String character)
        Determines whether or not the given character has special permission to be passed to the inputControl while the popup is showing or, to be exact, when the user has made the choice and the popup will be hidden soon.
        Parameters:
        character - the character to evaluate.
        Returns:
        true if the given character is has special permission; false otherwise.

      • getDisplayedSoundChoice

        protected java.lang.String getDisplayedSoundChoice()
        Should the popup be showing at the moment of calling this function and should it be populated, it will return the character that corresponds with the PhoneticSoundsChoice currently populating the popup. If, for example, aSounds constitutes its content, "a" will be returned.
        Returns:
        the character corresponding to the current content of the popup.
